biogHists.text:
Dr. A. Cooke Hull (1818-1868) was a resident of Brooklyn, a physician, a trustee of Public Schools 8 and 11 in Brooklyn, and a founder of the Long Island Historical Society (now the Brooklyn Historical Society).

From the guide to the A. Cooke Hull election petition and memorial book, 1865-1868, (Brooklyn Historical Society)

relations.content: Brooklyn (New York, N.Y.). Dept. of Public Instruction.
Flatlands School District No. 2 (Flatlands, New York, N.Y.)

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <unittitle>George G. Brown letter to John L. Rider regarding Brooklyn Board of Education allotment of funds</unittitle>
                  <unitid>1977.501</unitid>
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Brooklyn Historical Society</corpname>
                  </repository>
                  <langmaterial>
                     <language/>
                  </langmaterial>
                  <container>A0071</container>
                  <physdesc>
                     <extent>0.01 Linear feet</extent>
                     <extent>in one folder.</extent>
                  </physdesc>
                  <unitdate>1895</unitdate>
                  <abstract>Letter sent form George G. Brown, Secretary of the Brooklyn Department of Public Instruction, to John L. Rider, Supervisor of Flatlands, regarding the Brooklyn Board of Education allotting $342.00 to the the trustees of Flatlands School District No. 2. The letter is dated July 10, 1895.</abstract>
                  <origination>
                     <corpname>Brooklyn (New York, N.Y.). Dept. of Public Instruction.</corpname>
                  </origination>
               </did>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: George G. Brown letter to John L. Rider regarding Brooklyn Board of Education allotment of funds 1895
resource.abstract: Letter sent form George G. Brown, Secretary of the Brooklyn Department of Public Instruction, to John L. Rider, Supervisor of Flatlands, regarding the Brooklyn Board of Education allotting $342.00 to the the trustees of Flatlands School District No. 2. The letter is dated July 10, 1895.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <mods xmlns="http://www.loc.gov/mods/v3">
                  <recordInfo>
                     <recordOrigin>WorldCat:155460440</recordOrigin>
                     <recordContentSource>ISIL:NIC</recordContentSource>
                  </recordInfo>
                  <titleInfo>
                     <title>Brooklyn public education collection, 1843-1972.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>Publications of the Brooklyn and New York City Board of Education including charters, bylaws, annual reports, reports to teachers and parents, the course of study, school discipline and progress reports.  Also several histories of particular schools, publications about segregation in Brooklyn, 1850-1897, and a 1968 report on decentralization and discrimination. </abstract>
                  <name>
                     <namePart>Unknown</namePart>
                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>
                     </role>
                  </name>
               </mods>
            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: Brooklyn public education collection, 1843-1972.
resource.abstract: Publications of the Brooklyn and New York City Board of Education including charters, bylaws, annual reports, reports to teachers and parents, the course of study, school discipline and progress reports.  Also several histories of particular schools, publications about segregation in Brooklyn, 1850-1897, and a 1968 report on decentralization and discrimination.
